p: In the in-vitro experiments shown in Figure 2A, TS Oil inhibited CCh (1 µM) and K + (80 mM)-induced contractions. A higher potency was observed against CCh with EC50 measurement of 0.86 mg/ml (0.64–1.24, n = 4) as compared to high K + where the obtained EC50 value was 5.24 mg/ml (4.22–6.34, n = 5). A positive control drug, dicyclomine, behaved in a pattern similar to TS Oil against CCh and K + (80 mM) with respective EC50 values of 0.48 µM (0.38–0.52, n = 4) and 5.16 µM (4.86–6.62, n = 4) ( Figure 2B). On the other hand, unlike the plant oil and dicyclomine, verapamil was found more potent against K +-induced contractions with an EC50 value of 0.44 µM (0.32–0.58, n = 3) as compared to CCh-mediated contractions with EC50 value of 5.27 µM (4.55–6.42, n = 3) as seen in Figure 2C. Results of atropine, as shown in Figure 2D, show only selective relaxation against CCh with EC50 measurement of 0.06 µM (0.04–0.07, n = 3), while zero efficacy was observed against high K +.
